Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis of McCall Glacier Ice Core and Related Modern Process Studies
Award.AbstractNarration: This is a collaborative project involving four institutions. The proposed research addresses two major questions related to climate in the eastern Alaskan Arctic: 1) How has climate, terrestrial ecology, and pollutant transport changed over the past 250 years in this region, based on ice core reconstructions from McCall Glacier? and 2) How well can we overcome the challenges of core proxy interpretations from ice cores taken from small polythermal valley glaciers through modern-process studies? To answer these questions the investigators conduct an inter-disciplinary analysis of ice core proxies, atmospheric dynamics, modern processes, and numerical ice flow modeling. A 152-meter long core has already been drilled through McCall Glacier and analyzed for 35 chemical proxies. The proposed work will focus on 1) interpretation of these proxies, 2) analysis of pollen in the core, 3) process studies to identify sources of pollen to McCall Glacier, 4) tying the weather and climate record of the past 50 years to the upper section of the core, 5) continuing 3D flow modeling of the glacier and local weather observations, 6) conducting modern process investigations of the effects of seasonal melt on the generation of the core proxy record. The project will support two graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerosols are small droplets or particles in the air and in precipitation. Their sources include forest fires, volcanic eruptions, blowing desert dust, sea spray, and in the recent past, industrial emissions from fossil fuel burning, smelting, and other human activities. There are many reasons to better understand the sources, concentrations, and sources of aerosols in the past. For example, toxic heavy metals from industrial activities, volcanic eruptions and forest fires impact human and ecosystem health, while soot from fossil fuel combustion, wildfires, and agricultural burning changes the radiative properties of the atmosphere and Earth’s surface (especially snow) and so directly are linked to past, present and future climate change.

Aerosol records preserved in glaciers and ice sheets and sampled using ice core measurements offer the most direct and accurate way to reconstruct past changes in aerosols. Such records are developed routinely from the very cold, high elevation parts of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets. However, sources of aerosols like forests or factories often are located far from the polar ice sheets. While aerosol records are much more difficult to develop from lower latitude or lower elevation valley glaciers and small ice caps, they offer the possibility of developing records from many more regions the Earth, leading to better understanding of aerosol sources and concentrations. Low elevation sites are relatively warm even in the high-latitude Arctic so reliable chemical measurements are challenging and accurate interpretation illusive because water from melting of surface snow percolates into the snowpack, redistributing water (which refreezes to ice) and chemical impurities and making dating of the ice core records particularly problematic. The primary objective of this project was to develop and validate a detailed record of aerosols from the McCall Glacier ice core using novel measurements of a broad range of elements and chemical species; and interpret the record using atmospheric and meteorological models and other techniques. A secondary objective was to develop a record of past snowfall at the site to better understand why the glacier has declined in size during the past ~100 years. McCall Glacier is a relatively small valley glacier in the Brooks Range of northern Alaska and one of the very few places to collect an ice core in that part of the Arctic. 

Evaluation and interpretation of the McCall Glacier measurements is ongoing but it is clear that reliable records of aerosols and snowfall have been developed. The record extends from AD ~1800 to 2008 when the core was drilled and provides a detailed record of changes in aerosols from industrial emissions as well as fossil fuel and wildfire burning. Analyses using past meterological patterns suggests that different aerosols reflect different atmospheric circulation patterns, bringing specific aerosols from specific source regions to McCall Glacier where they are deposited. Snowfall at the ice core site has been surprisingly constant throughout the ~200 year period of the record.
